text: Any latex/typography expert around here? I'm trying to figure out the integral symbol in unicode fonts. There are two different ones, the small one for inline math (U+222B) and the big (glorious) one for separate equations, but I can't figure out where is the latter located in the font set (currently New Computer Modern). Context: trying to implement a simple TeX engine to have nice math symbols in Makie.

text:
look at
<http://mirrors.ibiblio.org/CTAN/fonts/newcomputermodern/newcm-unimath-symbols.pdf>
The first column is NewComputerModern section 9 shows \int u+222B
to get a very large integral sign one combines the top and bottom parts:
see \inttop and \intbottom (u+2320 and u+2321) on pg 27

in math mode you can use
```\displaystyle\int```
for a larger integral sign
